title: 114_hr4042
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pre-K for USA Act." Congress finds that the United States ranks 25th in early learning enrollment, with studies showing that access to high-quality prekindergarten programs leads to academic success and reduces the likelihood of negative outcomes such as drug problems and incarceration. Additionally, every public dollar spent on prekindergarten programs yields a $7 return through reduced spending on other services. Despite these benefits, about 40 percent of school districts do not offer prekindergarten programs. Texas missed out on up to $118.48 million in Federal funding to expand prekindergarten programs, as the state legislature cut approximately $5.4 billion in education funding in 2011. In response, certain local governments funded full-day prekindergarten programs, highlighting the need for direct application prekindergarten Federal program funding for localities. SEC. 3. PREKINDERGARTEN DEVELOPMENT GRANTS. The Secretary of Education, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will award competitive grants to increase capacity for high-quality prekindergarten programs. Grants will be awarded for up to 3 years and applications must be submitted by Governors or chief executive officers of eligible entities. States must consult with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care when developing their grant applications. To be eligible for a grant under this Act, a State must consult with the State Advisory Council on Early Childhood Education and Care and provide non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 20% of the grant amount. The matching funds can come from State funding, local funding, philanthropy, or in-kind contributions. The Secretary may waive the matching requirement in cases of financial hardship. The Secretary may waive or reduce matching funds for entities facing financial hardship when applying for a grant. Grant recipients can use funds to award subgrants to eligible local entities for grant activities. The subtitle allows grant funds to be used for subgrants to local entities for grant activities. Subgrantees must comply with Act requirements. The Secretary cannot award a subgrant if the State or entity already received funding for the program in that fiscal year. Authorization of appropriations is set at $750,000,000 for fiscal year 2016 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2017 through 2025. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "eligible local entity" refers to a local educational agency, early childhood education program provider, or a consortium of these entities. The term "full-day" means a day equivalent to a full school day in the state and not less than 5 hours. "High-quality prekindergarten program" is a program supported by an eligible local entity. A high-quality prekindergarten program supported by an eligible local entity must serve children aged 3 or 4, or those who have reached the legal age for State-funded prekindergarten. It also requires teachers to have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field with coursework in early childhood education. The teacher must have a bachelor's degree in early childhood education or a related field, demonstrate knowledge through a State-approved assessment, engage in ongoing professional development for 2 years, and be enrolled in a State-approved educator preparation program for support in early childhood education. The teacher in the program must have ongoing training and support in early childhood education, maintain a maximum class size of 20 children, have a child to instructional staff ratio of 10 to 1, offer a full-day program, and provide developmentally appropriate learning environments aligned with State standards. The program offers a full-day program, developmentally appropriate learning environments, salaries comparable to K-12 teaching staff, ongoing monitoring for improvement, and comprehensive services including screenings and family engagement opportunities. The program provides family engagement opportunities, nutrition services, and coordinated programs. The program offers nutrition education, physical activity programs, and additional support services based on needs analysis. The program provides high-quality professional development for staff, meets education performance standards, and maintains evidence-based health and safety standards. It also offers additional support services based on needs analysis. The terms "local educational agency" and "State" are defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education.
